author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Nearly a third of the U.S. faces excessive heat, with misery spreading to the coasts.
description: Record temperatures are possible again on Wednesday as an unrelenting heat wave streches to more of the country.
content: About 100 million Americans from California to New England were sweating through heat advisories and warnings from the National Weather Service on Wednesday, with a brutal heat wave across the central part of the country showing no signs of letting up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor, Isabella Kwai, Euan Ward and Aurelien Breeden
title: Europe’s Heat Wave: 5 Things to Know
description: Britain’s record-breaking heat has mostly abated, but fires still rage in Greece, Portugal and Spain.
content: Most of Europe slid back into more typical summer temperatures on Wednesday morning, but the aftermath continued from the record-setting heat wave that threatened lives, destroyed buildings and upended daily routines for much of the continent this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Chipotle closes a Maine store, and workers say it’s because of a union drive.
description: The shutdown was announced hours before a hearing on a possible vote to unionize the location, which employees said was understaffed.
content: Workers who filed for a union election at a Chipotle in Augusta, Maine, are accusing the company of seeking to undermine their campaign by closing the restaurant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Skewers Steve Bannon
description: “Finally, Bannon can tell the former president’s side of the story,” Colbert said on Tuesday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Grode
title: In a New Take on ‘Gaslight,’ a Heroine Finds Her Own Way
description: At this year’s Shaw Festival in Ontario, a favorite melodrama is reimagined, and other plays grapple with femininity and gender fluidity.
content: NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario — Nobody is coming to rescue Bella Manningham. And that’s a good thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Woman Posing as Nurse Tried to Steal Baby From Hospital, Authorities Say
description: Jesenea Miron is accused of entering a hospital in Moreno Valley, Calif., “posing as a newly hired nurse” and trying to take a newborn from a patient’s room.
content: A California woman was arrested on kidnapping and child-stealing charges after she posed as a nurse, gained access to a hospital maternity ward and tried to steal a baby from a patient’s room, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Eric Nagourney
title: Russia Signals That It May Want a Bigger Chunk of Ukraine
description: A top Russian official said Moscow may extend its territorial claims to include not just the east of Ukraine but also parts of the south.
content: Russia’s top diplomat said Wednesday that his country’s territorial ambitions in Ukraine might broaden, as European leaders warned their citizens to prepare for sacrifices in the face of a conflict that shows no sign of ending any time soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Fighting a Brutal Regime With the Help of a Video Game
description: Opponents of the coup in Myanmar have flocked to a new online game that lets players shoot virtual soldiers while raising money for the real-life resistance.
content: U Sein Lin, a retired history teacher in Myanmar, had never played a video game in his life. But about a month ago, while scrolling through Facebook, he stumbled on War of Heroes — The PDF Game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Pearl Jam’s Eddie Vedder Suffers Throat Damage From Europe’s Wildfires
description: The band canceled a show in Vienna after Mr. Vedder sought treatment following a musical festival in Paris.
content: The band Pearl Jam canceled its show in Vienna on Wednesday, saying that heat, dust and smoke from the wildfires across Europe had damaged the throat of its lead singer, Eddie Vedder, at an outdoor show in Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Weiner
title: Michael Mann’s Damaged Men
description: In “Ferrari,” his first film since 2015 — and in “Heat 2,” his first ever novel — the director returns to his great theme: outsiders with a brutal determination to win.
content: Michael Mann stood at the center of a long, sunlit room, scrutinizing a model of the Ferrari factory as it looked in 1957, thinking about how to improve its appearance. “This should be a pattern,” he said, pointing at the windows, “so that you have almost a musical rhythm, like, two-two-two-two-two, then it breaks, to drive your attention to the entryway.” Around him, a half-dozen collaborators listened closely. After Mann’s decisions were finalized, a construction team would be dispatched to a nearby site to build a replica of the 1957 factory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crummey
title: Read Your Way Through Newfoundland
description: Michael Crummey, an award-winning author whose poetry and prose explore the region and its capital, St. John’s, shares book recommendations, local vocabulary and where to find a good pint.
content: In relative terms, Newfoundland is very recently domesticated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Profit Falls in Second Quarter as Supply Chain Problems Hurt
description: The world’s largest maker of electric cars struggled with production problems in China.
content: Tesla said Wednesday that profit in the second quarter fell nearly one-third from the first quarter as deliveries slowed because of shutdowns and raw materials shortages at the carmaker’s factory in Shanghai.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jose Solís
title: An Immersive ‘Next to Normal’ Debuts in Barcelona
description: The Broadway musical and its Tony-winning star, Alice Ripley, return to the stage in this condensed and deconstructed production.
content: BARCELONA, Spain — When Tom Kitt and Brian Yorkey began writing their 2008 rock musical, “Next to Normal,” they wanted to create a piece in which, according to Yorkey, they could “bring the audience into the mind of the main character.” That character, Diana Goodman, is a suburban wife and mother with bipolar disorder who grapples with the harrowing symptoms of her mental illness while trying to maintain a functional life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: Caster Semenya, Barred From Her Signature Event, Races the 5,000 Meters
description: Semenya, the two-time Olympic champion and three-time world champion at 800 meters, is not permitted to compete in her favorite event this week.
content: Caster Semenya of South Africa, the two-time Olympic champion and three-time world champion at 800 meters, is not permitted to compete in her favorite event this week at the world track and field championships because of rules governing intersex athletes and permissible testosterone levels in events from the quarter mile to the mile, which combine speed and endurance.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Poetry and artillery: A reading list for war.
description: Even the newest of correspondents knows not to go into a war zone without the right training, the right gear, and the right exit plan. But some seasoned reporters have learned that they need something more to sustain them through the bleak days and nights of carnage: poetry.
content: Even the newest of correspondents knows not to go into a war zone without the right training, the right gear, and the right exit plan. But some seasoned reporters have learned that they need something more to sustain them through the bleak days and nights of carnage: poetry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia Expands Its Territorial Ambitions
description: Also, Sri Lanka elected a new leader and Britain narrowed its prime minister race to two candidates.
content: Russia’s top diplomat said Wednesday that his country’s territorial ambitions in Ukraine might broaden as European leaders warned their citizens to prepare for sacrifices in the face of a conflict that shows no sign of ending anytime soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: Twitter Takes Round 1
description: Judge Kathaleen McCormick granted the social media giant’s request for an expedited hearing. Now, the two sides are gearing up for a trial in October.
content: Twitter won its effort to expedite its trial with Elon Musk yesterday, in its lawsuit to force Musk to close his $44 billion acquisition of the company. So many people tried to listen to the proceedings that the dial-in hit capacity — and we hear advisers across Wall Street were huddled around speakerphones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Dan Cox, a Trump Loyalist, Wins Maryland’s G.O.P. Primary for Governor
description: Mr. Cox, who wrote on Twitter during the Capitol riot that Mike Pence was a “traitor,” defeated Kelly Schulz, who had been backed by Gov. Larry Hogan. The Democratic primary was too close to call.
content: Republican voters in Maryland on Tuesday made their state the latest to elevate a nominee for governor who denies the 2020 election’s legitimacy, choosing Dan Cox, a first-term state legislator who wrote on social media during the Capitol riot that Vice President Mike Pence was “a traitor.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: Giuliani Ordered to Testify in Georgia Criminal Investigation
description: After Rudolph W. Giuliani failed to show for a hearing in Manhattan, a Georgia judge ordered him to testify as part of an investigation into election interference in the state.
content: A Georgia judge ordered Rudolph W. Giuliani to testify in Atlanta next month in an ongoing criminal investigation into election interference by former President Donald J. Trump and his advisers and allies, according to court filings released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: London Shows How Unprepared Northern Cities Are for a Warmer World
description: As the heat wave rolled out, it left behind fears about how Northern European cities can cope with extreme weather driven by global warming.
content: LONDON — When storm clouds rolled into London on Tuesday evening, the rain brought with it much-needed relief for sweltering city residents after a day of record-breaking heat that drove wildfires, disrupted train travel and strained the city’s infrastructure and health services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: A Chocolate Cake for the Queen of ASMR Eating
description: A surprising online discovery leads to an unlikely friendship and a heartfelt cake recipe.
content: The sound of people eating, chewing, enjoying food makes me sleepy, which is unfortunate, considering that I cook for a living. I’ve had this, let’s call it “gift,” for as long as I can remember. It could have been anything: my father’s snacking on salted peanuts while watching the Golf Channel; a classmate’s opening a bag of chips in the library, crinkling the crispy polypropylene; the clickety-clacking of a lozenge around the mouth of my third-grade teacher, Mrs. Smith, while she explained an assignment, each word trailing off in my ears as I fell asleep at my desk. Though I didn’t know it at the time, these eating sounds gave me a relaxing, tingling sensation in my brain, an auditory-tactile synesthesia that scientists call A.S.M.R., or autonomous sensory meridian response. For me, that response is instantaneous somnolence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Henrik Stenson Stripped of Ryder Cup Captaincy as LIV Golf Rift Widens
description: Stenson was removed shortly before an announcement that he’d joined the Saudi-financed series. Former President Trump, whose course will host the next LIV series event, urged players to “take the money.”
content: Saudi Arabia’s contentious effort to buy its way into professional golf created a new flash point in the sport on Wednesday with the announcement that Europe’s team for next year’s Ryder Cup was dropping its captain, Henrik Stenson of Sweden, just ahead of his expected move to the new Saudi-financed LIV Golf series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Nope’ Review: Hell Yes
description: Jordan Peele’s genre-melting third feature stars Daniel Kaluuya and Keke Palmer as brother-and-sister horse wranglers defending the family ranch from an extraterrestrial threat.
content: The trailers for Jordan Peele’s “Nope,” one of the most feverishly anticipated movies of the summer, have raised some intriguing questions. Is it a western? A horror film? Science fiction? Satire? Will it fulfill the expectations raised by Peele’s first two mind-bending, zeitgeist-surfing features, “Get Out” and “Us,” or confound them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Lacking Motivation, Magnus Carlsen Will Give Up World Chess Title
description: “I don’t have any inclination to play,” the reigning world champion said in announcing he would not defend his crown next year.
content: Magnus Carlsen is the world chess champion, and by acclamation one of the very best players in history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Reporter Says Taliban Forced Her to Publicly Retract Accurate Articles
description: A veteran war reporter in Afghanistan was told she would go to jail if she didn’t tweet an apology for her reporting. She has since safely left the country.
content: The Taliban forced a longtime war correspondent to publicly retract some of her articles this week, telling her that she would go to jail if she did not, she said, in the latest crackdown on press freedom in Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Korsha Wilson
title: To Celebrate Black Life and Leisure, a Picnic in Central Park
description: In the lead-up to Juneteenth, Amber Mayfield hosted an outdoor potluck for friends and fellow foodies.
content: It’s early afternoon on a warm Saturday in June, and Sheep Meadow in Manhattan’s Central Park is awash with people relaxing on blankets and lawn chairs, laughing and chatting as they sunbathe or catch up over snacks. “I honestly had forgotten how busy it can get in the park,” says Amber Mayfield, 29 — the founder of the New York event agency To Be Hosted, and of While Entertaining, a magazine dedicated to showcasing the talents of Black foodies — as she surveys the scene, to which she will soon add.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Sean Kelly, Early National Lampoon Troublemaker, Dies at 81
description: He helped set the magazine’s irreverent tone with his pitch-perfect parodies. He also wrote lyrics for the Off Broadway Lampoon show “Lemmings.”
content: Sean Kelly, a wry master of literary and musical parodies who helped infuse National Lampoon with the sharp-edged and often crude humor it became known for, died on July 11 in Manhattan. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Quidditch Becomes ‘Quadball,’ Leaving J.K. Rowling Behind
description: Citing trademark concerns and objections to the author’s views on transgender issues, the sport’s leading groups officially distanced themselves from their “Harry Potter” roots.
content: Quidditch, the sport of boarding school wizards riding broomsticks in “Harry Potter,” will become “Quadball” to the humans who play the game in real life, its leading organizations said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: New Findings Detail Trump Plan to Use Census for Partisan Gain
description: A new trove of memos and emails suggests that the plan to add a citizenship question to the 2020 census aimed to cause an undercount that would favor Republicans.
content: A new stash of documents obtained by Congress has confirmed that the Trump administration pushed to add a citizenship question to the census to help Republicans win elections, not to protect people’s voting rights, a House committee report concluded on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Jonathan Weisman
title: Delay as the New Denial: The Latest Republican Tactic to Block Climate Action
description: The party has largely moved beyond denying the existence of climate change but continues to oppose dramatic action to halt it, worried about the short-term economic consequences.
content: WASHINGTON — One hundred million Americans from Arizona to Boston are under heat emergency warnings, and the drought in the West is nearing Dust Bowl proportions. Britain declared a climate emergency as temperatures soared above 100 degrees Fahrenheit and parts of blistering Europe are ablaze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Seeking ‘Axis of Good’ Against U.S., Russia Taps Allies of Convenience
description: A trilateral meeting of the leaders of Iran, Russia and Turkey seemed to suggest a new anti-American alliance. But there are major fissures between the countries, too.
content: BRUSSELS — Commenting on the visit of Vladimir V. Putin to Iran, a member of the Russian Parliament and television talking head, Yevgeny G. Popov, said that the two countries hoped to form an “axis of good,” mocking former President George W. Bush’s description of Iran, Iraq and North Korea as an “axis of evil.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Futterman
title: Leading Russian Tennis Player Criticizes War in Ukraine
description: After calling the war a “nightmare” and coming out as gay in an interview, Daria Kasatkina, the highest-ranked Russian woman, said she worried for her safety if she returned to her home country.
content: For the first time since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, a Russian tennis player has publicly criticized the war, a move that may land her in trouble if and when she returns to her home country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: For a Revered Art House Cinema, a Season of Off Screen Turmoil
description: The Jacob Burns Film Center in Westchester, a celebrated venue that enjoys backing from cinema’s A-list, has been roiled by the dismissal of one of its original leaders who was accused of bullying behavior.
content: For more than two decades, the Jacob Burns Film Center in Westchester County has been a glimmering success story: an oasis for film lovers drawn to the art house cinema’s offerings and the panache of its A-list leaders, members and visitors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Sydney McLaughlin’s youth track coach knew what was coming.
description: “That girl is the truth,” Lisa Morgan, McLaughlin’s youth coach, recalled saying after seeing her run as a young teen.
content: There is no shortage of late bloomers at the track and field world championships, those athletes whose world-class talents did not emerge until they fully matured. For some, it can happen in their mid- or even late twenties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: It’s Time to Slow Down and Appreciate Nature’s Tiny Marvels
description: Grab your iPhone: Andrew Brand wants to show you a side of your garden that you’ve never seen before (and how to photograph it).
content: “Look at that caterpillar,” Andrew J. Brand said one afternoon, as we passed a hummocky old bottlebrush buckeye shrub in my garden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Ukraine steps up attacks on key Russian targets in the south.
description: Attacks on a strategically important bridge and other Russian positions in the Kherson Province over the last two days raise a question: Is Ukraine preparing a larger counteroffensive?
content: A critical bridge shelled. A fighter jet shot out of the sky. Ammunition depots destroyed. A cluster of soldiers attacked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: The Antihero’s Last Gasp
description: Since the beginnings of Batman, pop culture has embraced the figure who lives on the boundary between law and lawlessness. With truth and justice now seemingly up for grabs, do those stories still make sense?
content: In the popular Amazon Prime series “The Boys,” Hughie, an irrepressibly earnest young man who runs with the title group of misfits, is forced to decide — several times — if he’s willing to sell his soul to the devil in exchange for justice. And by “the devil” I mean Billy Butcher, the ruthless, potty-mouthed leader of the team of soldiers and assassins devoted to fighting, extorting, torturing and killing superheroes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: A Fourth Vaccine
description: And hope for enjoying the summer season.
content: The United States approved its fourth vaccine for use against the coronavirus. The new vaccine from Novavax,  a Maryland pharmaceutical company, works differently from the three other Covid vaccines in use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eva Goldfarb and Lisa Lieberman
title: After Roe, Sex Ed Is Even More Vital
description: Reducing unwanted pregnancies starts with teaching children and teenagers.
content: Religious-right political groups that have spent decades dismantling abortion rights in much of the country have been gunning for sex education for just as long. Their dangerous and cynical efforts now appear under the guise of “parental rights” and “school transparency” on the floors of state legislatures and at school board meetings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Patricia Cohen
title: Seeking Leverage Over Europe, Putin Says Russian Gas Flow Will Resume
description: President Vladimir Putin warned that the Nord Stream 1 pipeline to Germany would not operate at full capacity after maintenance work.
content: BERLIN — When the main natural gas artery between Russia and Germany, the Nord Stream 1 pipeline, was taken off-line last week for 10 days of scheduled maintenance, European leaders began bracing for the possibility that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia would not switch it back on as retaliation for opposing Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here’s what to watch at the world championships on Wednesday
description: Watch the 400-meter hurdles semifinals, and catch the steeplechase final.
content: If Tuesday night reminded us of anything, it’s that no one is guaranteed a gold. So watch the 400-meter hurdles semifinals (you never know!) and catch the steeplechase final.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: 14-Year-Old Dies After Being Shot in Harlem, Police Say
description: The boy was one of two who were shot on the street Tuesday afternoon by a gunman who was apparently targeting them, officials said.
content: A 14-year-old boy has died after being shot in the head on a Harlem street on Tuesday afternoon in what appeared to be a targeted attack, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: We May Never See Another Skater Like Yuzuru Hanyu.
description: The Japanese skater retired from competition with two Olympic gold medals, two world championship gold medals and more stuffed Winnie the Pooh bears than anyone can count.
content: Yuzuru Hanyu, the two-time Olympic champion, said on Tuesday that he would no longer participate in competitions, and the landscape of the sport of figure skating will never be the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: F.D.A. Seeks Outside Review of Troubled Food and Tobacco Units
description: The agency’s commissioner asked an external foundation to examine its operations in the wake of the baby formula and vaping crises.
content: The Food and Drug Administration has commissioned a review of its food and tobacco programs following public outrage over baby formula shortages and concerns about flavored nicotine products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: These Fins Were Made for Walking … and Then Swimming
description: Around 375 million years ago, a giant fish evolved limbs for walking. But some of its descendants reversed course on the evolutionary road, becoming swimmers again.
content: One of the biggest myths of evolution is that it is a relentless march of progress. In fact, evolution is not a linear track, but a branching tree. New species do not arise as part of some long-term goal; they adapt to new opportunities in their surroundings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: CNN Chairman Chris Licht Picks Leadership Team for Post-Zucker Era
description: Mr. Licht, who joined CNN after a stormy period at the network, has chosen a band of insiders to lead it.
content: CNN’s chairman, Chris Licht, has settled on a new leadership team for the network’s news and business sides, picking mostly from the ranks of insiders who worked for his predecessor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Harris Jewelry will pay refunds and stop loan collections to settle predatory-lending charges.
description: The now-defunct retailer sold overpriced goods to members of the military with high-interest loans, prosectors said.
content: Harris Jewelry, a now-defunct jewelry retailer that government officials said had preyed on military families by selling them overpriced baubles using high-interest loans, will pay millions in refunds and stop collecting on its loans in a settlement deal announced on Wednesday by the Federal Trade Commission and 18 state attorneys general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Stanton and Buxton Power A.L. to Ninth Straight All-Star Win
description: Back-to-back homers off Tony Gonsolin were enough give the American League yet another victory in the Midsummer Classic.
content: The fans were denied a first-of-its-kind Swing-Off tiebreaker, but home runs decided the All-Star Game anyway. Giancarlo Stanton and Byron Buxton hit back-to-back blasts in the fourth inning, powering the American League to a 3-2 win over the National League on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss Will Compete to Replace Boris Johnson
description: The two emerged as the final candidates after five rounds of voting, and now will try to win over an electorate that had wearied of Mr. Johnson’s seemingly endless scandals.
content: LONDON — Britain’s Conservative lawmakers settled on their choices to succeed Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Wednesday, advancing two candidates who worked for Mr. Johnson to replace a leader whose scandal-scarred tenure ended with his government in disarray, at a time of deepening economic crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Albert Vann, Who Built a Black Power Base in Brooklyn, Dies at 87
description: As a legislator for four decades, he led voter registration drives and challenges to redistricting that rattled the political establishment.
content: Albert Vann, who as a progressive New York State and New York City legislator for four decades helped shift the Black political center of gravity from Harlem to Brooklyn, where he challenged the white-dominated Democratic machine, died on Friday at his home in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of the borough. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘The Gray Man’ Review: Guy vs. Guy
description: Ryan Gosling plays a blasé government operative opposite Chris Evans’s showy psychopath in this globe-trotting spy action movie.
content: The frenetic caper “The Gray Man,” from the directors Anthony Russo and Joe Russo, boasts more vibrant color than the typical globe-trotting shoot-em-up about the C.I.A., a distinctly drab organization. The Russos’ lead, an agent known as Six (Ryan Gosling), wears a snazzy red suit with matching fingernail polish to his first onscreen assassination. Six works for his freedom, not his 401(k): He is a convicted murderer who was plucked from prison by a government suit (played by Billy Bob Thornton) and placed in a secret kill squadron. He seems to be OK with the deal, despite showing a light layer of fatigue that Gosling wears like a rain poncho.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Pence Campaigns for House Republicans, Papering Over Party Rift
description: Mike Pence has quietly helped Republican candidates despite their loyalty to Donald J. Trump and support for his election lies, which placed Mr. Pence’s life at risk.
content: WASHINGTON — As Representative Darin LaHood, Republican of Illinois, prepared to campaign with Mike Pence, the former vice president, in his district last month, he braced for a backlash from his party’s right-wing base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Holding Out for a Hero? Ballet Theater Has It Covered.
description: Daniel Camargo’s breakout season at American Ballet Theater changed his rank from guest artist to principal. (Now, all he needs is an apartment.)
content: As soon as Daniel Camargo mentioned his early love of the ballet video “Born to Be Wild: The Leading Men of American Ballet Theater,” his dancing immediately made sense — the brash attack, the dramatic flair, the boundless energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender and Reid J. Epstein
title: Trump Recently Urged a Powerful Legislator to Overturn His 2020 Defeat in Wisconsin
description: Donald J. Trump called Robin Vos, the speaker of the Wisconsin Assembly, on July 9 and pushed him to support a resolution to retract the state’s 10 electoral votes for President Biden.
content: Donald J. Trump called a top Republican in the State Legislature in Wisconsin in recent days to lobby for a measure that would overturn his 2020 loss in the state to President Biden, the latest signal that the former president remains undaunted by congressional and criminal investigations into his election meddling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Sorry, Summer
description: We all know what happened with summer 2020. Then 2021 was dampened by Delta. This year, any anticipated return to revelry has been hampered by … *waves hands at everything.* Is there hope for enjoying the once fun season?
content: Timothy Hale had high hopes for this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Robert F. Curl Jr., Nobel Prize Winner in Chemistry, Dies at 88
description: He and three others discovered unexpectedly simple carbon molecules called buckyballs (think of a soccer ball), spurring explorations of nanotechnology.
content: Robert F. Curl Jr., who shared the 1996 Nobel Prize in Chemistry as one of the discoverers of remarkably simple but completely unexpected carbon molecules known as buckyballs, died on July 3 at a retirement home in Houston. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Explaining who we are.
content: The New York Times Company owns The New York Times newspaper, website and app, and several other businesses:
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Energy War Escalates
description: Europe plans to force gas rationing to deal with Russia’s likely supply cutoff.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Uvalde Superintendent Recommends Firing School Police Chief
description: Chief Pete Arredondo has been criticized for a delay of more than an hour in entering the classroom where a gunman had fatally wounded 19 students and two teachers.
content: SAN ANTONIO — Facing widespread public pressure, the school superintendent in Uvalde, Texas, has recommended firing the school district police chief, Pete Arredondo, for his role in the delayed response to a mass shooting that allowed a gunman to remain in two classrooms full of surviving students for more than an hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Streaming Is Sadder Now
description: When Netflix and other companies face a loss of faith in the growth potential of streaming, we all will feel it.
content: It may not yet be noticeable when we flop on the sofa and flip on Netflix, but the golden age of streaming entertainment might be over. We probably won’t like what happens next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: R&B That Sweats, Emotionally and Physically
description: New releases from Brent Faiyaz and Muni Long show how the genre has evolved in recent years.
content: There’s a beautiful, crabby song in the middle of “Wasteland,” the new album by the singer and songwriter Brent Faiyaz, called “Rolling Stone.” The synthesizers are operating at full throb, what sounds like a meandering flute wanders in and out, and there are no discernible drums. Faiyaz opens with a lamentation: “I’m a rolling stone/I’m too wild for you to own,” then turns defensive, complaining, “First I’m exciting, then I’m gaslighting/Make up your mind.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: Apple Agrees to $50 Million Settlement Over Butterfly Keyboard Complaints
description: A class-action lawsuit represented customers who sought repairs for the troubled MacBook keyboard, released in certain laptops from 2015 to 2019. Many were frustrated by typing errors.
content: Apple agreed on Monday to pay a $50 million settlement on a class-action lawsuit over so-called butterfly keyboards, a component of some MacBook laptops that left many users fuming in key-smashing frustration over typing failures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: In ‘The Kingdoms of Savannah,’ Oddballs Circle Around a Murder Mystery
description: George Dawes Green’s new novel hammers home the ugliness undergirding the city’s flowery, fashionable beauty.
content: Writer’s block has gone lamentably out of fashion, with people posting on the internet for free at all hours, the James Patterson conveyor belt, etc. So an author who takes a nice long time between books can provoke special affection and attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Hochul says N.Y. students probably won’t have to mask, but keeps a public transit mandate.
description: As coronavirus hospitalizations and deaths in New York tick up as a result of the rapidly spreading Omicron subvariant known as BA.5, Gov. Kathy Hochul held her first Covid briefing in months.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York said Wednesday that she did not anticipate schoolchildren would need to wear masks when they return to school in September, but that she was keeping the statewide mask mandate on public transportation for now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Why Is It So Hard to Adapt Austen? The Fans Play a Part.
description: The backlash to the Netflix version of “Persuasion” has as much to do with who’s watching as who’s scripting. Still, the new film broke some rules.
content: Few authors (leaving aside Shakespeare, always a special case) have had their works reimagined as frequently, or as liberally, as Jane Austen. Onstage, onscreen and in books, her novels have been recast as slapstick farces, fantasy mash-ups, all-hands-on-deck Bollywood extravaganzas and saucy rom-coms. They have been transported to, among other places, Cincinnati, Delhi, Fire Island, Los Angeles, modern London and, in the case of the “Pride and Prejudice”-inspired vampire novel “Twilight,” the sleepy town of Forks, Wash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Miles Bridges Faces Felony Domestic Violence Charges
description: Bridges, a Charlotte Hornets free agent, was accused of assaulting his girlfriend in front of their two children. He was arrested in Los Angeles last month.
content: Miles Bridges, a Charlotte Hornets free agent, will be arraigned Wednesday on felony charges of domestic violence and child abuse, the Los Angeles County District Attorney’s Office announced Tuesday. Bridges, 24, faces one count of injuring a child’s parent and two counts of child abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: With Russian Cutoff Feared, Europeans Are Told to Curb Natural Gas Use
description: The European Union’s executive branch says member countries must cut consumption by 15 percent between now and the springtime to stave off a major crisis as Russia weaponizes its exports.
content: BRUSSELS — Europe must cut its use of natural gas by 15 percent from now through next spring to prevent a major crisis as Russia slashes gas exports, the European Union’s executive branch said on Wednesday, calling for hard sacrifices by the people of the world’s richest group of nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Bipartisan Senate Group Strikes Deal to Rewrite Electoral Count Act
description: The changes outlined by the senators are intended to prevent a repeat of the effort on Jan. 6, 2021, to overturn the presidential election in Congress.
content: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of senators proposed new legislation on Wednesday to modernize the 135-year-old Electoral Count Act, working to overhaul a law that President Donald J. Trump tried to abuse on Jan. 6, 2021, to interfere with Congress’s certification of his election defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel
title: As crypto swoons, Anthony Scaramucci struggles to keep investors.
description: The hedge fund manager, who did a brief stint in Trump’s White House, is facing a wave of redemption requests amid lackluster performance.
content: Has “The Mooch” lost his mojo?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mireille Silcoff
title: Dove’s Latest Stand in the Virtue Wars
description: How they managed to claim the high ground against other brands while remaining as broadly inoffensive as any giant company desires.
content: Last week, I sat down with my 10-year-old daughter to watch a short video titled “Toxic Influence” — a product of the Dove Self-Esteem Project. We watched as five sets of moms and their daughters appeared in turn on upholstered chairs before a big screen, glasses of water trembling between the generations. Text appeared: “We invited parents and their girls to talk about social media.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport, Lisa Friedman and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Announces Plans to Deal With Climate ‘Emergency’
description: The president stopped short of declaring a national emergency and instead announced several steps aimed at dealing with the effects of climate change.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Wednesday that he would expand existing federal programs to help Americans cope with the extreme heat wrought by climate change, even as he faces intensifying pressure to take aggressive action to cut the fossil fuel emissions that are dangerously warming the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: As Buffalo Supermarket Reopens, Memories of Massacre Haunt Workers
description: Two months after 10 were killed at Tops Friendly Market, employees and Masten Park residents confront the pain of returning and remembering.
content: BUFFALO — As the sun rose over Jefferson Avenue, early light fell gently upon a handful of people standing at a sidewalk memorial outside a neighborhood grocery. Dressed in identical black shirts emblazoned “All One,” they watched as the chain-link fence that had surrounded their workplace for two months was stripped away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Glamour, Lust and Murder in the Hallowed Halls of Oxford
description: In Ruth Ware’s “It Girl,” a woman whose college roommate was murdered decides to reinvestigate the case.
content: Nuclear Armageddon, killer viruses, massive tidal waves, alien attacks, apocalyptic space debris — there are so many ways it could go wrong for our battered little planet. In AURORA (Harper, 292 pp., $27.99), David Koepp offers a new unpleasant scenario, a solar storm called a coronal mass ejection that summarily knocks out most of the world’s power. (In a neat trick, the cataclysm barely touches the countries nearest to the Equator, which immediately offer humanitarian aid to the struggling nations of Europe and North America.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson, Emma Bubola and Camilla Ferrari
title: Italy Is Haunted by the Pain of Past Economic Crises
description: As the European Central Bank prepares to raise interest rates for the first time in more than a decade, the challenges for one of the bloc’s largest economies balloon again.
content: TREVISO, Italy — In the flat plains of Italy’s Veneto region, in a small town about 20 miles north of Venice, Antonio Carpenedo has been developing unusual methods of making cheese. At La Casearia Carpenedo, wheels of cheese are dunked and aged in wine — red, white and Prosecco — while others are covered in hay and aged in barrels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Why Do Moms Tend to Manage the Household Scheduling?
description: Are we in a “transitional” moment for dads?
content: Sonya Bonczek wanted to make sure she was inviting all of her son’s favorite kids to his 4th birthday party, which is in August. But she quickly realized she didn’t have all of their parents’ email addresses, and her son’s preschool doesn’t give them out. When she saw one of these parents at pickup, she flagged him down and asked for his contact info for an Evite. “Let me give you my wife’s,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Mujib Mashal
title: Ally of Ousted Sri Lanka President Is Chosen to Replace Him
description: Ranil Wickremesinghe, a canny political survivor with ties to the exiled former president, inherits a nation in deep crisis.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — The election of Ranil Wickremesinghe as president of Sri Lanka on Wednesday represented the triumph of establishment politics over a social movement calling for wholesale change. The fervent protests cost a family dynasty its seats in government, but so far, not its influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Prosecutors Rest in Contempt Case Against Steve Bannon
description: The government, seeking to hold Mr. Bannon to account for defying a subpoena from Congress, wrapped up its case after calling just two witnesses.
content: WASHINGTON — The prosecution rested its case on Wednesday in the trial of Stephen K. Bannon, a former top adviser to President Donald J. Trump, as government lawyers sought to show that Mr. Bannon had repeatedly ignored warnings that he risked facing criminal charges in flouting a subpoena.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Waves, Perhaps
description: Josh Kindler’s Wednesday puzzle offers a refreshing break in the middle of our week.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Josh Kindler, the constructor of today’s grid, who is making his debut in the New York Times Crossword. It’s absolutely wicked, and I hope you enjoy solving it as much as I did. For anyone looking to start constructing puzzles, here is my guide to resources. You can also find help in the Crossword Puzzle Collaboration Directory group on Facebook or the Crosscord Discord server.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Koichi Nakano
title: Shinzo Abe Failed to Rearm Japan. Let’s Keep It That Way.
description: Japan has a chance to repair relations with neighbors angered by his nationalist agenda.
content: TOKYO — Japan had barely begun processing the shock of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s assassination by a gunman on July 8 before attention turned to whether his quest to remilitarize Japan, including the revision of its pacifist Constitution, would survive him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Inflation Is Bad, but Unemployment Is Far Worse
description: The case for moving cautiously with interest rates.
content: What’s worse, higher inflation or higher unemployment? That question is at the core of the debate over how rapidly the Federal Reserve should raise interest rates to cool off the economy and bring inflation down from its 40-year highs. If you think higher inflation is worse, then it makes sense to raise rates hard and fast, even at the cost of causing a recession. If you think higher unemployment is worse, then moving cautiously is a better choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Futterman
title: The highest-ranked Russian in women’s tennis calls the war ‘a full-blown nightmare.’
description: For the first time since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, a Russian tennis player has publicly criticized the war, a move that may land her in trouble if and when she returns to her home country.
content: For the first time since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, a Russian tennis player has publicly criticized the war, a move that may land her in trouble if and when she returns to her home country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: HarperCollins Workers Strike For Increased Wages, Benefits and Diversity
description: The one-day action, unionized employees said, was intended to draw attention to core problems with the publishing industry.
content: HarperCollins union members went on a one-day strike on Wednesday, with around 100 employees and additional supporters marching in front of the company’s corporate headquarters in Manhattan in the sticky heat for higher wages, better family leave benefits and a stronger commitment to diversity from the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: As Temperatures Rise, ‘This Is a Preview.’ Will the Warning Be Heard?
description: Record heat and rampant fires are raising grim questions about the world’s ability to withstand a new era of climate change.
content: It is very, very hot in London. As I wrote this column on Tuesday, the temperature had climbed to the hottest ever recorded in England, exceeding 40 degrees Celsius, or about 104 Fahrenheit, for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Give Duke Ellington the 1965 Pulitzer Prize
description: An overdue reckoning worth reckoning with.
content: Want racial reckoning? Then it’s time to give Duke Ellington the Pulitzer Prize he was unjustifiably denied in 1965. The jazz scholar Ted Gioia has circulated a Change.org petition with this call, and as of this writing, it has surpassed 6,000 signatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Nina Feldman, Mooj Zadie, Rob Szypko, Clare Toeniskoetter, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: How Abortion Bans Are Restricting Miscarriage Care
description: The reversal of Roe v. Wade has caused some doctors to worry that recommending certain procedures might have legal repercussions.
content: Across the United States, Republicans emboldened by the overturning of Roe v. Wade are passing laws intended to stop medical staff from providing an abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: What are the signs of heat stroke?
description: The symptoms of heat stroke, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, include a high body temperature (103 degrees Fahrenheit, or 39.5 degrees Celsius, or higher); hot, red, dry or damp skin; a fast and strong pulse; a headache; dizziness; nausea; confusion and passing out. If someone is experiencing these symptoms, call your local emergency number and try to move the person into the shade or a cooler area. You can also use cool cloths or a cool bath to lower the person’s body temperature. Do not give him or her anything to drink.

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: ‘Boomerang’ at 30: Think of It as the Robin Givens Rom-Com
description: It’s remembered as Eddie Murphy’s bid at romantic stardom and as a key point in Halle Berry’s career. But the riveting antagonist arguably created a new archetype.
content: It was the summer before my first year of college, and I was enthralled by a movie (and its music) that had just arrived in theaters: “Boomerang,” starring Eddie Murphy. But I was drawn to the movie’s antagonist, Jacqueline Broyer, the glamorous, ambitious advertising executive. Played by Robin Givens, she was one of the few African American female characters to be the main love interest in a romantic comedy at the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Britain sets a heat record.
content: Britain made meteorological history yesterday when temperatures in some places topped 40 degrees Celsius (104 degrees Fahrenheit) for the first time on record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Draghi Government Falls Apart, Returning Turbulent Politics to Italy
description: Days after he tendered his resignation, the Italian leader tried one more time to convince the country’s fractious parties to hang together. They refused.
content: ROME — The national unity government of Prime Minister Mario Draghi, who restored Italy’s influence and credibility, fell apart on Wednesday, leaving the country careening toward a new season of political chaos at a critical moment when the European Union is struggling to hold together a united front against Russia and revive its economies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Kestenbaum
title: Keeping the Hippie Dream Alive
description: Sound baths, cannabis prayers and sunset howls: DoubleBlind, a California media company, tries to revive the psychedelic spirit for a new generation.
content: The guide stood before a small group in a dimly lit tepee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: A View From the Right on Progressives’ ‘Moral Crusade’
description: Noah Rothman and Alex Kingsbury debate whether the left actually has a problem with fun.
content: For years, Republicans have been known as the party of moral outrage. Take for instance the recent book banning wars, or Florida’s “Don’t Say Gay” bill. But Democrats aren’t immune to moral outrage. At least that’s what Noah Rothman, a conservative writer and commentator, believes. He is the author of the new book “The Rise of the New Puritans: Fighting Back Against Progressives’ War on Fun.” In it, he argues that progressives, in their pursuit of liberal ideals, are fueling a movement of moral panics more reminiscent of 17th-century preachifying than 1960s liberalism — and that we’re all worse off for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Have You Been Reinfected With Covid?
description: We’re looking for advice on getting through an infection.
content: Early in the pandemic, many people assumed that infection with the coronavirus meant they were no longer at risk of a repeat bout of the illness. There was even talk about “the immunes” — people who recovered and went back to their lives while the rest of us were locked down at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Survey Looks at Acceptance of Political Violence in U.S.
description: Nearly 12 percent of respondents said it was at least “sometimes justified” to use violence if it meant returning Donald J. Trump to the presidency.
content: One in five adults in the United States would be willing to condone acts of political violence, a new national survey commissioned by public health experts found, revelations that they say capture the escalation in extremism that was on display during the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta and Melissa Eddy
title: War and Warming Upend Global Energy Supplies and Amplify Suffering
description: First, Russia upended the world energy market, then searing temperatures drove up demand for energy, forcing some of the world’s largest economies to scramble to secure power for their citizens.
content: Deadly heat and Russia’s war in Ukraine are packing a brutal double punch, upending the global energy market and forcing some of the world’s largest economies into a desperate scramble to secure electricity for their citizens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: ‘None of us has a crystal ball’: Scientists try to keep up with faster coronavirus evolution.
description: Health officials are trying to make far-reaching policy decisions, including on booster shots, based on little biological certainty of which viral variants will be dominant.
content: The rapid evolution of the coronavirus into an alphabet soup of subvariants presents a vexing challenge to health officials: They must make far-reaching policy decisions based on little biological certainty of which viral variants will be dominant this fall or winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hikari Hida and Tiffany May
title: Sea Turtles Found Stabbed in Japan, but Charges Are Unlikely
description: Despite being endangered, green sea turtles are not protected by the country’s conservation laws. They often get tangled in nets, to the annoyance of fishermen.
content: TOKYO — The stabbings of endangered sea turtles on the pebbled coastline of Okinawa has shocked Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: Was This the Art Party of the Summer?
description: O’Flaherty’s, a gallery in the East Village, invited everyone to submit work. Then it held an opening.
content: Gallery openings tend to be staid affairs. White wine, art-world hobnobbing and maybe dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.8 Million Homes in New York, Florida and Virginia
description: An 1838 cottage in East Hampton, a three-bedroom bungalow in Miami Shores and a Spanish Colonial Revival house in Richmond.
content: This house was once owned by Nicolas Carone, an abstract expressionist painter and a member of a group of New York artists that included Willem de Kooning, who rented the property while his studio was under construction nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sangar Khaleel and Cora Engelbrecht
title: Turkish Warplanes Strike Iraq Resort, Killing at Least 8, Officials Say
description: The attack came in a region that Turkey targets because Kurdish militants take refuge there, in a new flaring of regional tensions.
content: ZAKHO, Iraq — Turkish warplanes struck a vacation resort in northern Iraq on Wednesday, killing at least eight people and injuring more than 23, according to government and hospital officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Who Will Make Apple Fashionable Now?
description: With the metaverse looming, a shift in designer could make a big difference.
content: So Jony Ive, the former Apple chief design officer and consultant, and the man most responsible for the visual allure of Apple products — the man who helped transform computers and phones into objects of desire, who made them more than mere vectors of functionality, but rather badges of identity — and his erstwhile employer have reportedly agreed to sever their last ties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: A Bold Concert of Songs and a Potent Play Leave Audiences Abuzz
description: At the Williamstown Theater Festival, Daniel Fish’s “Most Happy in Concert” confounds and Anna Ouyang Moench’s “Man of God” raises its own question.
content: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — The Saturday matinee of “Most Happy in Concert” had just let out at the Williamstown Theater Festival, and grumbling disgruntlement hung in the air, along with surprised puzzlement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Heat Wave: Why Home Offices Add to Con Ed’s Stress
description: As temperatures reach the mid-90s, New York’s electrical system will face an additional burden because of people working from home.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Can the electrical system in New York City handle the heat wave? We’ll check on why the answer is a bit different than it was before the pandemic. We’ll also look at why the Manhattan district attorney dropped a murder charge against a bodega clerk who stabbed an attacker to death.

title: Can Fashion Influencers Persuade Us to Consume Less? A Times Virtual Event
description: Join Vanessa Friedman on July 28 as she explores how popular culture and the influencer economy might shift the industry toward responsible fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: British Inflation Climbs to 9.4 Percent, a New 40-Year High
description: The prices of food and fuel continued to rise fast, and consumers were squeezed as wages failed to keep up.
content: Consumer prices in Britain rose 9.4 percent in June from a year earlier, intensifying the squeeze on household budgets as inflation continued to run at its fastest pace in 40 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Western Europe, Climate Leader
description: Yet it’s suffering badly from warming.
content: Western Europe has done more to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions over the past three decades than any other region in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: The Biden administration will challenge Mexico’s state control of its energy industry.
description: The move stems from concerns that Mexico is violating the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, which seeks to level the playing field for industries across the continent.
content: The Biden administration plans to request consultations with the Mexican government over energy policies that the United States believes have hurt American companies, an action that could result in punitive tariffs on Mexico if attempts to resolve the dispute fail, the administration said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Biden’s Climate Change ‘Revolution’ Isn’t Coming
description: Where will environmental politics go from here?
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: United Airlines hits a revenue milestone, but costs constrain its quarterly profit.
description: The carrier expects travel demand to remain strong, despite concerns about a recession.
content: United Airlines on Wednesday reported revenue of $12.1 billion in the three months that ended in June, its largest quarterly haul in at least a decade and the most it has ever earned in the second quarter of a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: America’s Safety Net for Workers Hurt by Globalization Is Falling Apart
description: A 60-year-old program that provides retraining to workers whose jobs are eliminated because of foreign competition has expired, leaving many at risk.
content: WASHINGTON — In September, the lighting factory in Logan, Ohio, where Jeff Ogg has clocked in nearly every day for the last 37 years, will shut its doors, driven out of business by a shift from fluorescent lighting toward LED technology that is often made cheaply in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: If Oil Drilling Ends in California, What Happens to Oil Country?
description: In Kern County, oil and gas generate tax revenues that keep schools open and police departments funded.
content: Long a leader in environmental regulation, California is considering phasing out oil drilling in the state by 2045 as part of an effort to reduce carbon emissions that contribute to global warming.

author: By Clay Risen
title: William Hart, Driving Force Behind the Delfonics, Dies at 77
description: With hits like “La-La (Means I Love You)” and “Didn’t I (Blow Your Mind This Time),” his group pioneered the soulful Philadelphia sound.
content: William Hart, who as the lead singer and chief lyricist of the soul trio the Delfonics helped pioneer the romantic lyrics, falsetto vocals and velvety string arrangements that defined the Philadelphia sound of the 1960s and ’70s, died on July 14 in Philadelphia. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Korsha Wilson
title: Let Your Taste Buds Be Your Guide
description: In all five boroughs (plus Jersey City), options abound to explore neighborhoods through restaurants and tours. Here are one food lover’s suggestions.
content: Summer days and warm weather mean lots of time for meandering and exploring parts of town you’ve never been to or may have overlooked. description: The Manhattan district attorney’s office arranged the transfer of items it had seized, including a fresco from a town that was covered in ash after the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in A.D. 79.

title: Driver Hits Family in Montana and Opens Fire, Killing Father and Toddler
description: David Siau and his 18-month-old daughter, McKenzie, were killed when Derick Amos Madden rammed his vehicle into the family in East Glacier Park, Mont., and shot at them, the authorities said.
content: A man struck a family with his vehicle as they were walking beside a roadway near Glacier National Park in Montana on Sunday and then fired at them with a shotgun, killing a man and his 18-month-old daughter, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: What to Know About Jafar Panahi, the Imprisoned Iranian Filmmaker
description: The auteur is now serving a sentence that Iran’s judiciary handed down in 2010 when he was arrested for supporting protests.
content: On Tuesday, Jafar Panahi, the award-winning Iranian filmmaker, was ordered to serve a six-year prison sentence by Iran’s judiciary. author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Alison dos Santos upset Karsten Warholm in the 400-meter hurdles.
description: Warholm, the world-record holder, appeared to be in control much of the race. But it was Dos Santos who was able to find another gear in the final straight away.
content: Alison dos Santos of Brazil upset Karsten Warholm, the star quarter-mile hurdler from Norway, and Warholm’s chief rival, Rai Benjamin of the United States, throwing a major curveball in the rematch of one of the great races of last year’s Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Endemic Covid-19 Looks Pretty Brutal
description: 100,000 annual deaths may be as good as it gets.
content: It may surprise you to learn, given the mood of the country — and indeed the world — about the pandemic that probably half of all Covid infections have happened this calendar year — and it’s only July. By December, the figure could be 80 percent or more. The gap between cases and severe outcomes is bigger than it has ever been, with the fraction of infections ending in deaths one-tenth that of the pandemic’s early stages. But simply in terms of infection, this year towers over each of the previous two.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Dobbins
title: It’s not easy being a fishing guide when your lake dries up.
description: Says one tackle shop owner in Texas: “We’ve got $5-a-gallon gasoline and border issues, but low water is our biggest problem.”
content: SAN ANTONIO — Amid one of the hottest Texas summers on record and a deepening drought, Lake Amistad, the international reservoir that straddles the border of Mexico and Texas, is only a few centimeters above its lowest level ever recorded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Tired of Waiting for Their Dream Workplace, These Writers Made Their Own
description: After years of being put through the wringer of New York City media, five journalists created Hell Gate, the blog-style news site run on their terms.
content: About halfway through 2021, Christopher Robbins had had enough. Laid off from a job he had cared about deeply after witnessing multiple media organizations in New York City collapse over the years, Mr. Robbins was ready to free himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Michigan Coach Jim Harbaugh Speaks at Anti-Abortion Event
description: The remarks by Harbaugh, who was quoted as saying, “I believe in having the courage to let the unborn be born,” run counter to those expressed by the university’s interim president.
content: Jim Harbaugh, the University of Michigan’s head football coach, professed his anti-abortion views at a fund-raising event this week, becoming one of the first prominent sports figures to speak out against abortion since Roe v. Wade was overturned.

title: The Shame Game

author: By Elisa Gabbert
title: Chance, Design and Inevitability in Three New Poetry Books
description: Reviews of Brenda Coultas’s “The Writing of an Hour,” Paul Tran’s “All the Flowers Kneeling” and Ryann Stevenson’s “Human Resources.”
content: Some people believe that before we are born, we choose our own parents. In a poem called “The First Number Will Be a Blues,” Sommer Browning describes one version of this story: “Before we’re born, my mother tells us, / We watch movies of every life we might be born into. Then we choose. / The little baby points from her / astral cradle.” The speaker marvels at the implications: “I choose that mama. / I choose that daddy. / I choose that irrevocably broken marriage, / That accident that wires my jaw shut, / That burned popcorn” — the litany continues — “That root canal, that unending night on mushrooms, / That dog bite.” “That DUI.” Is it absurd to imagine we select our own pattern of suffering, or that we might have picked a life without any? As Willard Spiegelman notes in his book “Seven Pleasures,” “‘Hap’ means chance.” Happiness and happen share the same root. Whether we choose them or not, the random happenings of our lives, good and bad, are our own. The details that add up to days and years — your street name, your first word, your favorite podcast — have what Ernest Becker might have called a “cosmic specialness.”

The 43-year-old artist, who was born in Queens to Trinidadian parents, has been a relentless advocate for the cause of valuing and protecting the lives of Black people.
